title: Number of homes coming up for sale slumps to the lowest level since 2016
text:
The number of homes coming up for sale has fallen to the lowest level for three years, as a stand-off between would-be buyers and sellers takes hold.

'Endless wrangling' over Brexit continues to hamper the housing market, estate agents told the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors in their latest survey.

With would-be sellers nervous about putting their home up for sale, the number of properties on estate agents' books remains close to a record low.

Sluggish: The number of homes coming up for sale has fallen to the lowest level for three years

The number of new inquiries from buyers and agreed sales also slipped last month, the Rics survey reveals.

Simon Rubinsohn, Rics' chief economist, said: 'There are good reasons for thinking the latest dip in both buyer inquiries and vendor instructions is a response to the endless wrangling about Brexit, as the October 31 deadline approaches.

'Unless there is a speedy resolution to the ongoing impasse, it does seem inevitable that the stand-off between purchasers and sellers will deepen, making it harder to complete transactions.

'This will not only be a direct hit on the housing market itself but could have ramifications for the wider economy as the normal spend on furniture, fittings and appliances that typically accompanies a house move is also put on hold.'

Under pressure: The Brexit saga continues to take its toll on the housing market

Forecast: National sales expectations in the UK over the next three and 12 months

An overall net balance of 37 per cent of surveyors reported the supply of homes being put up for sale decreasing rather than increasing in September, marking the weakest reading since June 2016.

The housing market seems unlikely to gain impetus over the next three months, although sentiment for a year ahead is a little more resilient, Rics said.

The buyer inquiries balance fell to -15 per cent, pointing to a 'modest' decline in buyer demand.

Meanwhile, the agreed sales balance, a measure of the anticipated volume of transactions, slipped to -27 per cent, against -11 per cent a month earlier, with activity reportedly slipping in virtually all parts of the country.

The Rics house prices balance, which measures the difference between the number of estate agents and property surveyors anticipating increases and those expecting decreases, returned a reading of -2 per cent in September, little changed from -4 per cent in August.

House prices remained 'broadly flat' last month, the Rics said.

'Negative momentum' in London and the South East's property markets is holding back average national property price growth, the survey said.

But, some locations, including Scotland, Northern Ireland and the North West saw 'solid gains' in the house price stakes last month.

Sluggish: New seller instructions in the last month, according to the Rics

Price matters: Predictions for house prices over the next three and twelve month period

Kevin Hay, of Allied Surveyors in Scotland, said: 'There is definitely a degree of uncertainty in the market due to Brexit.'

Meanwhile, Richard Taylor, of London’s Surveyors & Valuers, said: 'Brexit once again dominates the conversation, although investors are now as (or more) concerned about the effects a Labour administration will have on the property market.'

In September, the Office for National Statistics published official house price data for July. In the year to July, property prices rose by 0.7 per cent, down from a 1.4 per cent rise in the year to June.

This is the lowest annual rate since September 2012, when it was 0.4 per cent. Over the past three years, there has been a general slowdown in UK house price growth, driven mainly by a slowdown in the south and east of England.

The lowest annual growth was in the North East, where prices fell by 2.9 per cent over the year to July. This was followed by the South East, where prices fell by 2 per cent over the year.
description: With would-be sellers nervous about taking the plunge and putting their home up for sale, the number of properties on estate agents' books remains close to a record low.
